author: Teknanam

text:
But you are wrong there. K Rool and the rest of the Kremlings appeared in post Rare video games.

Donkey Konga
DK: King of Swing
Donkey Kong Barrel Blast

And I haven't even counted the spin-off Nintendo games like Mario Super Sluggers and Smash Bros. Brawl. The Kremlings ARE owned by Nintendo. They just didn't want to use them in Returns.
author: Teknanam

text: I believe a big part of this is licensing - You'll notice that Kremlings and K.Rool are gone from the DK games after Rare went to Microsoft.  A pity, as the Kremlings were quite memorable compared to the today's Tikis

text: @pelletier1986 peace man, what your doing is great. I find that if you give a kid a fond memory of an old game, they will return to it in later life, and realise that old games rock loads. I mean i first played mario 64 back in 2000 when i was 5, that got me into nintendo, which in turn (due to their extensive history) got me into retro gaming, and now i can appreciate a game reguardless of it age :D so keep it up!
author: Koopsas

text: @sora8711 It really depends on if you want to base a majority onto a minority, i mean i dont know which age group you mean  when you refer to the said group as "kids" but there are young adults out there who love old games. Im only 15, but i can appreciatea game if it came out yesterday on the ps3, or in 1983 on the zx spectrum, personly im underwhelmed by the shooter genre as a whole, with the biggest exection being timesplitters 2.
